Module 1: Multiple-Affirmative Questions

For students

Last updated: 30/01/2026 20:16

The questions are based on or inspired by the following references:

  • Berk & DeMarzo, Corporate Finance, 5th ed. (2020)
  • Brealey & Myers, Principles of Corporate Finance, 13th ed. (2020)

Q1.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A venture capital fund is typically organized as a limited partnership
  2. Limited partners work for the fund and make the investment decisions
  3. General partners manage the fund and choose investments

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) In standard VC structures, the fund vehicle is typically a limited partnership, while the venture capital firm/manager is a separate management company. This statement is treated as false here because it conflates the fund vehicle with the manager‚Äôs organizational form. - (2) Limited partners (LPs) are investors who provide capital but do not run the fund; general partners (GPs) manage the fund and make investment decisions.

Q2.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A primary offering in an IPO sells only existing shares and raises no cash for the firm
  2. A secondary offering increases the number of shares outstanding
  3. An IPO is the first sale of stock to the public

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A primary offering issues new shares, increasing shares outstanding and raising cash for the firm (secondary offerings sell existing shares). - (2) A secondary offering sells existing shares (often by insiders); it typically does not increase shares outstanding or raise new cash for the firm.

Q3.

Consider the following statements:

  1. In a firm commitment IPO the underwriter makes a best efforts promise and does not guarantee sale
  2. In a best efforts IPO the underwriter guarantees sale of all shares at the offer price
  3. A best efforts deal can include an all or none clause

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) In a firm commitment IPO, the underwriter commits to buy the shares from the issuer and resell them‚Äîeffectively guaranteeing the sale at the offer price. - (2) In a best efforts IPO, the underwriter does not guarantee selling all shares; it only agrees to use its best effort to place them.

Q4.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A greenshoe provision is a restriction that prevents insiders from selling shares after an IPO
  2. A lockup provision allows the underwriter to sell extra shares at the offer price
  3. A lockup restricts insiders from selling shares for a period after the IPO

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A greenshoe (overallotment) option lets the underwriter sell additional shares at the offer price; restrictions on insider sales are lockups. - (2) Selling extra shares at the offer price is the greenshoe; lockups restrict insider selling.

Q5.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Underpricing means the IPO offer price is above the first day market price on average
  2. Money left on the table is negative when the first day closing price exceeds the offer price
  3. Money left on the table equals the first day price jump times the number of shares sold

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Underpricing refers to IPO shares being offered below their aftermarket value (first-day market price tends to be higher than the offer price). - (2) Money left on the table is typically the first-day price increase times the number of shares sold; it is positive when the first-day price exceeds the offer price.

Q6.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Pre money valuation equals post money valuation plus the new investment
  2. Post money valuation excludes the new capital raised in the round
  3. Pre money valuation equals post money valuation minus the new investment

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Pre-money valuation is the value before the new investment: \(Pre = Post - Investment\). - (2) Post-money valuation includes the new capital raised: \(Post = Pre + Investment\).

Q7.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A down round occurs when a firm raises new funding at a higher price than a prior round
  2. Anti dilution protection decreases early investor ownership in a down round
  3. Anti dilution protection can increase early investor ownership in a down round

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A down round is when new financing occurs at a lower price/valuation than the prior round. - (2) Anti-dilution provisions protect earlier investors in a down round by increasing their effective ownership (typically by adjusting conversion terms).

Q8.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A rights offer sells new shares only to new outside investors
  2. Rights offers create a windfall for new investors at the expense of existing shareholders
  3. Rights offers can protect existing shareholders from underpricing

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A rights offering gives existing shareholders the right to buy new shares (typically to maintain their proportional ownership). - (2) Rights offerings are designed to protect existing shareholders (they receive rights); any discount is typically captured by existing shareholders who exercise or sell the rights.

Q9.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A registration statement is prepared after trading begins in the aftermarket
  2. A final prospectus is circulated before the offer price is determined
  3. A final prospectus includes the offer price and the number of shares offered

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A registration statement (e.g., S-1) is filed before the offering; it is required for registered public offerings. - (2) The final prospectus includes the final offer terms (including the offer price) and is finalized after pricing.

Q10.

Consider the following statements:

  1. In book building the offer price is set solely by a sealed bid auction rule
  2. A road show occurs after the IPO shares start trading
  3. Book building uses investor indications of interest to help set the offer price

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Statements (1) and (2) are false (statement (3) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Bookbuilding relies on investor indications of interest and underwriter discretion; it is not a pure sealed-bid auction rule. - (2) The road show happens before IPO pricing/trading, as part of marketing to investors.

Q11.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Carried interest is a fixed annual fee charged regardless of performance
  2. A typical management fee is charged on committed capital
  3. General partners are usually limited partners in the fund

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Carried interest is performance-based compensation (a share of profits), not a fixed annual fee. - (3) General partners and limited partners are different roles: GPs manage the fund; LPs provide capital and have limited control.

Q12.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Angel investors usually invest only after an IPO when market prices are stable
  2. Angels sometimes use a SAFE or a convertible note to postpone valuation
  3. A SAFE is common stock that pays a regular cash dividend

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Angel investors typically invest in early-stage private firms, well before any IPO. - (3) A SAFE is a contract that converts into equity in a future financing; it is not dividend-paying common stock.

Q13.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Convertible preferred stock cannot be converted into common stock
  2. Preferred stock in young firms often has seniority in liquidation
  3. Preferred stock in young firms typically pays regular cash dividends

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Convertible preferred stock gives the investor the option to convert into common stock under specified terms. - (3) Preferred stock in startups often has liquidation preference and other rights, but regular cash dividends are uncommon (cash is usually reinvested).

Q14.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Pari passu means later round investors are senior to earlier round investors
  2. Seniority terms can specify repayment priority across different rounds
  3. Seniority means all investors have identical priority in liquidation

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Pari passu means investors share the same priority (equal rank), not that later investors are senior. - (3) Seniority defines who gets paid first in liquidation; it can create different priorities across rounds, not identical priority.

Q15.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A seasoned equity offering is the first sale of stock to the public
  2. A seasoned equity offering is an equity issue by a firm that is already public
  3. A seasoned equity offering requires no disclosure because the firm is already public

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A seasoned equity offering (SEO) is an equity issue by a firm that is already public (the first public sale is an IPO). - (3) SEOs still require disclosures and filings (though requirements can differ from IPOs).

Q16.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Underpricing benefits pre IPO owners in a primary offering because they sell at the higher first day price
  2. Underpricing is a cost to pre IPO owners when shares are sold below aftermarket value
  3. Underpricing eliminates the need for any underwriter compensation

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) This statement is false because it contradicts standard equity issuance mechanics covered in the module (the correct relationship goes the other way). - (3) Underwriters are compensated through the spread/fees; underpricing is a separate cost borne by the issuer/old owners.

Q17.

Consider the following statements:

  1. An auction IPO allocates shares only to favored clients without any bidding
  2. An auction IPO sets the offer price based on bids that clear the market
  3. In an auction IPO the clearing price is always the highest bid price

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) Auction IPOs allocate shares based on bids and use a market-clearing rule, rather than discretionary allocations to favored clients. - (3) A clearing price is typically the lowest price that sells the offered quantity (the marginal bid), not necessarily the highest bid.

Q18.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A lockup provision allows insiders to sell immediately after the IPO
  2. A lockup restricts insiders from selling shares for about 180 days
  3. A lockup increases the number of shares outstanding

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) A lockup restricts insiders from selling their shares for a period after the IPO (often ~180 days). - (3) A lockup is a selling restriction; it does not change the number of shares outstanding.

Q19.

Consider the following statements:

  1. The spread is paid only when the first day return is negative
  2. The spread is the fee paid to underwriters and is often quoted as a percent of the issue price
  3. A higher spread always implies lower underpricing

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) The spread is the underwriters‚Äô fee (often a percent of the issue price) and is paid regardless of first-day returns. - (3) Spread and underpricing are different components of issuance cost; a higher spread does not mechanically imply lower underpricing.

Q20.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A corporate investor invests only for financial returns and never for strategic objectives
  2. Corporate investors may invest for strategic objectives in addition to financial returns
  3. Corporate investors are always prohibited from investing in private companies

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Statements (1) and (3) are false (statement (2) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (1) This statement is false because it contradicts standard equity issuance mechanics covered in the module (the correct relationship goes the other way). - (3) Corporate investors can and do invest in private companies (e.g., corporate venture capital).

Q21.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A venture capital firm is a limited partnership that raises money to invest in the private equity of young firms
  2. Limited partners run the venture capital firm and provide expertise to portfolio companies
  3. General partners supply most of the capital and are passive investors

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Limited partners (LPs) are investors who provide capital but do not run the fund; general partners (GPs) manage the fund and make investment decisions. - (3) General partners (GPs) manage the fund and are active; most of the capital typically comes from limited partners (LPs).

Q22.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Pre money valuation is the value of the firm before the new investment at the round price
  2. Pre money valuation includes the new cash raised in the round by definition
  3. Pre money valuation equals post money valuation plus the investment

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Pre-money valuation excludes the new investment; it is the value of the firm just before the new cash is added. - (3) Pre-money valuation is the value before the new investment: \(Pre = Post - Investment\).

Q23.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A primary offering increases the number of shares outstanding
  2. A secondary offering increases the number of shares outstanding
  3. A secondary offering raises new cash for the firm

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) A secondary offering sells existing shares (often by insiders); it typically does not increase shares outstanding or raise new cash for the firm. - (3) A secondary offering sells existing shares (often by insiders); it typically does not increase shares outstanding or raise new cash for the firm.

Q24.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A rights offer sells new shares to existing shareholders
  2. Rights offers always have higher issuance costs than cash offers
  3. Rights offers force every shareholder to purchase new shares

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Rights offerings can be cheaper than cash offers because underwriting/marketing needs are often lower, though costs depend on the deal. - (3) Shareholders can usually choose whether to exercise or sell their rights; rights offerings allow (not prevent) maintaining proportional ownership.

Q25.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A greenshoe provision allows the underwriter to sell additional shares at the offer price
  2. A greenshoe provision restricts insiders from selling shares after the IPO
  3. A greenshoe provision is the same as a lockup

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) A greenshoe (overallotment) option lets the underwriter sell additional shares at the offer price; restrictions on insider sales are lockups. - (3) This statement is false because it contradicts standard equity issuance mechanics covered in the module (the correct relationship goes the other way).

Q26.

Consider the following statements:

  1. IPO issuance is highly cyclical with booms in good markets and droughts in bad markets
  2. IPO issuance volume is constant across time and does not vary with market conditions
  3. The number of IPOs rises in bad markets and falls in good markets

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) IPO issuance is cyclical: it tends to increase in strong markets and fall in weak markets. - (3) IPOs tend to cluster in good markets; issuance typically falls during bad markets.

Q27.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A negative SEO announcement effect is consistent with adverse selection
  2. Adverse selection predicts firms issue equity only when undervalued
  3. Adverse selection predicts the stock price should rise on equity issuance news

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Adverse selection models predict firms are more likely to issue equity when they believe it is overvalued, which leads to a negative announcement reaction. - (3) With adverse selection, equity issuance signals potential overvaluation, so prices tend to fall on issuance announcements.

Q28.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Private equity firms often invest in existing privately held firms
  2. Private equity firms invest only in early stage startups
  3. Private equity firms never use debt in acquisitions

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Private equity firms commonly invest in more mature companies, including existing privately held firms and buyouts. - (3) Debt is frequently used in private equity transactions (notably in leveraged buyouts).

Q29.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A leveraged buyout can take a public firm private using debt and equity financing
  2. A leveraged buyout is financed only with equity and uses no debt
  3. A leveraged buyout is unrelated to taking a firm private

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) A leveraged buyout is characterized by substantial use of debt alongside equity. - (3) LBOs are often used to take public firms private (though they can also occur for private firms).

Q30.

Consider the following statements:

  1. In book building the underwriter collects indications of interest from investors
  2. In book building there is no marketing and no interaction with investors
  3. In book building demand information cannot affect the offer price

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Statements (2) and (3) are false (statement (1) is true). Why the false statements are false: - (2) Bookbuilding involves marketing (e.g., road shows) and collecting demand information from investors. - (3) In bookbuilding, demand information from investors is used to help set both allocation and the offer price.

Q31.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A primary offering raises cash only for existing shareholders and never for the firm
  2. A secondary offering always increases the number of shares outstanding
  3. An IPO is the process of selling stock to the public for the second time

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A primary offering issues new shares, increasing shares outstanding and raising cash for the firm (secondary offerings sell existing shares). - (2) A secondary offering sells existing shares (often by insiders); it typically does not increase shares outstanding or raise new cash for the firm. - (3) An IPO is the first time a firm sells its stock to the public.

Q32.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A firm commitment IPO means the issuer guarantees the shares will be sold
  2. A best efforts IPO means the underwriter guarantees sale of all shares at the offer price
  3. A firm commitment IPO removes all risk for the underwriter

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) In a firm commitment IPO, the underwriter (not the issuer) bears the placement risk by committing to purchase the shares. - (2) In a best efforts IPO, the underwriter does not guarantee selling all shares; it only agrees to use its best effort to place them. - (3) Firm commitment reduces placement risk, but underwriters still face price/market risk when reselling the shares.

Q33.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Underpricing means the offer price is set above the first day closing price on average
  2. Money left on the table is zero when the first day closing price exceeds the offer price
  3. Underpricing transfers value from old owners to new owners in a secondary offering by the firm

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) Underpricing refers to IPO shares being offered below their aftermarket value (first-day market price tends to be higher than the offer price). - (2) Money left on the table is typically the first-day price increase times the number of shares sold; it is positive when the first-day price exceeds the offer price. - (3) This statement is false because it contradicts standard equity issuance mechanics covered in the module (the correct relationship goes the other way).

Q34.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A lockup provision allows insiders to sell shares earlier than other investors
  2. A greenshoe provision prevents insiders from selling shares for 180 days
  3. A greenshoe provision is a restriction on insider sales and not an issuance option

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A lockup restricts insiders from selling their shares for a period after the IPO (often ~180 days). - (2) A greenshoe (overallotment) option lets the underwriter sell additional shares at the offer price; restrictions on insider sales are lockups. - (3) A greenshoe (overallotment) option lets the underwriter sell additional shares at the offer price; restrictions on insider sales are lockups.

Q35.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A registration statement is optional and is not required for an IPO
  2. A preliminary prospectus contains the final offer price and final share count
  3. A final prospectus is circulated before the offer price is determined

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A registration statement (e.g., S-1) is filed before the offering; it is required for registered public offerings. - (2) A preliminary prospectus typically excludes the final offer price and final share count; those are set at pricing. - (3) The final prospectus includes the final offer terms (including the offer price) and is finalized after pricing.

Q36.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A down round occurs when the firm issues new equity at a higher price than before
  2. Anti dilution protection increases founder ownership in a down round
  3. Anti dilution protection transfers value to founders and employees in a down round

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A down round is when new financing occurs at a lower price/valuation than the prior round. - (2) Anti-dilution provisions generally transfer value toward earlier investors (and away from founders/common holders) in a down round. - (3) Anti-dilution provisions generally transfer value toward earlier investors (and away from founders/common holders) in a down round.

Q37.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Corporate investors never pursue strategic objectives
  2. Institutional investors never invest directly in private firms
  3. Institutional investors include only individual retail investors

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) Corporate investors may invest for strategic reasons (e.g., access to technology/markets) in addition to financial returns. - (2) Many institutional investors (e.g., pension funds, endowments) invest in private markets, often via funds and sometimes directly. - (3) Institutional investors are organizations (e.g., mutual funds, pensions, insurers), not individual retail investors.

Q38.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Private equity firms invest only in early stage startups
  2. A leveraged buyout is financed only with equity
  3. Private equity acquisitions never use debt financing

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) Private equity firms commonly invest in more mature companies, including existing privately held firms and buyouts. - (2) A leveraged buyout is characterized by substantial use of debt alongside equity. - (3) Debt is frequently used in private equity transactions (notably in leveraged buyouts).

Q39.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A rights offer sells new shares only to new outside investors
  2. Rights offers create a windfall for new outside investors when priced below value
  3. Rights offers prevent existing shareholders from maintaining proportional ownership

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A rights offering gives existing shareholders the right to buy new shares (typically to maintain their proportional ownership). - (2) A rights offering gives existing shareholders the right to buy new shares (typically to maintain their proportional ownership). - (3) Shareholders can usually choose whether to exercise or sell their rights; rights offerings allow (not prevent) maintaining proportional ownership.

Q40.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A seasoned equity offering occurs when a private firm sells stock to the public for the first time
  2. In an SEO there is no existing market price for the stock
  3. SEOs are more costly than IPOs because spreads are higher

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: D. All three statements are false. Why the false statements are false: - (1) A seasoned equity offering (SEO) is an equity issue by a firm that is already public (the first public sale is an IPO). - (2) Because the firm is already public, an SEO typically has an existing market price to reference. - (3) This statement is false because it contradicts standard equity issuance mechanics covered in the module (the correct relationship goes the other way).

Q41.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A venture capital firm is typically organized as a limited partnership
  2. Limited partners supply most of the capital to the venture fund
  3. General partners manage the fund and select investments

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q42.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Angel investors are often wealthy individuals who invest in small private firms
  2. Angels sometimes use a SAFE or a convertible note to postpone valuation
  3. Early stage financing can avoid a firm valuation until a later round

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q43.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Convertible preferred stock gives the owner an option to convert into common stock
  2. Preferred stock in young firms often has seniority in liquidation
  3. Later rounds can have distinct security terms and provisions

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q44.

Consider the following statements:

  1. Pre money valuation equals post money valuation minus the new investment
  2. Post money valuation values old shares and new shares at the round share price
  3. In a priced round the new share price applies to both old shares and new shares

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q45.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A primary offering raises new capital for the firm
  2. A secondary offering sells existing shares and does not raise new capital for the firm
  3. An IPO is the first sale of stock to the public

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q46.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A firm commitment IPO means the underwriter guarantees sale of the shares at the offer price
  2. A best efforts IPO does not guarantee that all shares will be sold
  3. Best efforts deals can include an all or none clause

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q47.

Consider the following statements:

  1. The spread is a fee paid to underwriters and is quoted as a percent of the issue price
  2. Underpricing is a cost to pre IPO owners when the firm sells shares below aftermarket value
  3. Money left on the table equals the first day price jump times the number of shares sold

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q48.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A greenshoe provision allows the underwriter to sell additional shares at the offer price
  2. A lockup restricts insiders from selling shares for a period after the IPO
  3. Underwriters may help provide liquidity by making a market in the stock

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q49.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A seasoned equity offering is an equity issue by a firm that is already public
  2. SEOs can include primary shares and secondary shares
  3. SEO announcements are associated on average with a stock price decline

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.

Q50.

Consider the following statements:

  1. A rights offer sells new shares only to existing shareholders
  2. Rights offers can protect existing shareholders from underpricing
  3. Rights offers can be cheaper than cash offers because underwriting needs are lower

Which statements are FALSE?






‚úÖ Correct: E. None of the statements are false (all three are true). Why: All three statements are correct as written, so none are false.
